questionText: To which one of the following 802.11 frame types does a wireless device listen to identify potential access points on a channel?
explanation: Beacon frames are transmitted by wireless access points to advertise their presence on each channel and WLAN being served. Probe Request frames are also used to discover APs, but are transmitted only by wireless devices. Instead, devices listen for Probe Response frames sent to them by APs.

questionText: Which one of the following organizations has introduced the set of numbered Wi-Fi compatibility names and verification tests (that is, Wi-Fi 6, Wi-Fi 6E, and Wi-Fi 7)?
explanation: The complete set of Wi-Fi compatibility designations Wi-Fi 0 through Wi-Fi 7 was introduced by the Wi-Fi Alliance. The IEEE maintains the 802.11 Wi-Fi standard, and the FCC regulates interstate and international communications in the United States.

questionText: Wireless devices must adhere to which standard to provide network connectivity?
explanation: Wireless LAN devices must adhere to the IEEE 802.11 standard to operate properly and be compatible. The IEEE 802.1 standard is related to LAN/MAN bridging and management, 802.2 focuses on the logical link control in the data-link layer, and 801.11 does not exist.

questionText: Which one of the following correctly defines the purpose of a wireless ESSID?
explanation: Having a consistent SSID through the ESS is called an extended service set identifier (ESSID).

answerChoices.Text: The ESSID is used to uniquely identify each wireless device on a network.
The ESSID is used to identify an SSID that exists consistently through an extended service set.
The ESSID is used to uniquely identify each wireless AP.
The ESSID is not used at all; instead, only SSIDs and BSSIDs are used in wireless networks.

questionText: Which of the following frequency bands are commonly used for Wi-Fi networks?
explanation: Wi-Fi networks can use the 2.4, 5, and 6 GHz bands.

questionText: Which of the following statements are true about 802.11 wireless communication on a single frequency? Assume all devices are within range of each other.
explanation: Due to the nature of RF signals, only one device should transmit at any given time. If two or more devices transmit at the same time, they can interfere with each other enough that their signals cannot be successfully received. However, once one device transmits, any number of devices can receive its signal because it is freely available over the air.

answerChoices.Text: Two or more devices can transmit data to each other at the same time.
Two or more devices can receive data at the same time.
Only one device should transmit data at a given time.
Only an access point can transmit data on the frequency.

questionText: Which of the following parameters should be consistent on neighboring APs as a wireless client moves and attempts to roam from one AP to another?
explanation: The SSID string should be consistent across all APs so that wireless clients can roam from one AP to another, all while staying connected to the SSID and its WLAN. The clients will try to discover other nearby APs that offer the same SSID. The BSSID cannot be consistent across APs because it is unique to each AP and each WLAN on the AP. ESSID is not a valid term in the 802.11 standard, and BSAID is a fictitious term.”
comments: 10/2 - small change, but good as-is, 8/31 - query to Au

questionText: A wireless network consists of three APs, with four possible wireless LANs offered by each of the APs. Which of the following statements is true about this scenario?
explanation: All three APs can use the same SSID on a WLAN because the SSID is not unique among APs. In fact, the SSID should be identical on all APs so that wireless clients can roam from one AP to another while staying connected to the same SSID and wireless LAN. In contrast, the BSSID is unique to each AP and to each WLAN, so all three APs cannot use the same BSSID value. An AP cannot use the same BSSID on all four WLANs because the BSSID is unique across WLANs too. Finally, wireless clients cannot send frames to a specific AP by using only the SSID; the AP’s BSSID, essentially a MAC address, must be placed in the destination field of transmitted frames.

answerChoices.Text: All three APs use the same BSSID on a WLAN.
All three APs can use the same SSID on a WLAN.
One AP can use the same BSSID for all four WLANs.
Wireless clients can send frames to an AP by placing the AP’s SSID in the destination address field.

questionText: Suppose two APs are located near each other. Which channel use strategy will result in nonoverlapping channels for Wi-Fi use?
explanation:
For the correct answers, first note that using 2.4-GHz channel 1 and 5-GHz channel 48 would result in nonoverlapping channels because each is a member of a different frequency band. Also, using 5-GHz channels 36 and 40 would also result in nonoverlap because the usable 5-GHz channel numbers are spaced appropriately so that they do not overlap.

For the incorrect answers, in the 2.4-GHz band, channels 1 and 2 are spaced much too closely, causing extensive overlap. In the 5-GHz band, the available non-overlapping channel numbers increment by 4: channels 36, 40, 44, 48, and so on. So, the answer that suggests using 5 GHz channels 36 and 37 is invalid.

answerChoices.Text: Use 2.4-GHz channel 1 on AP-A and channel 2 on AP-B.
Use 2.4-GHz channel 1 on AP-A and 5-GHz channel 48 on AP-B.
Use 5-GHz channel 36 on AP-A and channel 40 on AP-B.
Use 5-GHz channel 36 on AP-A and channel 37 on AP-B.

questionText: Which of these terms refers to a name that wireless devices use to advertise a wireless network?
explanation:
The answers:

	- SSID: (Service Set Identifier) is a name of a Wi-Fi network that is advertised. Wireless devices can then join that Wi-Fi network.

	- Repeater: A type of device that extends wireless coverage

	- AP: (Access Point) has a wired connection to the LAN and also communicates with wireless devices.

	- Channel: Refers to frequencies that can be used to communicate over the Wi-Fi network. Sometimes you need to change the channel because there might be too much interference, or it is too busy.

questionText: How often are beacon frames sent by an AP on each channel and WLAN that it serves?
explanation: Beacon frames are transmitted by a wireless access point ten times per second (every 100 ms) on each channel and WLAN that the AP is operating.

questionText: Which device provides a basic service set?
explanation: A wireless access point provides a basic service set that wireless client devices can join and use for communication. A workgroup bridge acts as a client device, so it cannot provide a BSS. A wireless client cannot provide a BSS either. An antenna cannot provide anything on its own unless it is connected to an access point or a client device. Even then, it is the access point supplying the BSS.

questionText: A BSSID looks identical to which other network parameter?
explanation: A BSSID is identical to the AP’s wireless radio MAC address, along with an index to the wireless LAN that is being carried over the BSS. A BSSID cannot be a text string, whereas an SSID can. A BSSID is neither an IP address nor a frequency.

questionText: Which one of the following channel lists contains valid, nonoverlapping channels?
explanation: In the 2.4 GHz band, channels 1, 2, and 3 all overlap each other due to the wide channel bandwidth used by each. The same is true for channels 1, 3, and 6. Only channels 1, 6, and 11 are considered to be nonoverlapping. In the 5 GHz band, valid channel numbers increment by four, so channels 36, 37, and 38 are not all valid - only channel 36 is. Channels 100, 104, and 108 are all valid and separated by an increment of four.

questionText: To use nonoverlapping channels for your Wi-Fi network, which of these would be a correct strategy for neighboring access points?
explanation: In the 2.4-GHz band, each channel is much wider than the channel numbers are spaced. For example, you should use only channels that are at least five channel numbers apart, as in channels 1, 6, and 11. You could also use channels 4 and 9, but that would limit the number of possible channels that could be used. You should not use just any channel, as the APs could overlap with each other quite easily. You should not use the same channel on each Cisco AP because each AP will overlap and interfere with all others within range.

answerChoices.Text: Use any channel in the 2.4-GHz band.
Use only 2.4-GHz channels that are five channel numbers apart.
Use only 2.4-GHz channels that are four channel numbers apart.
Use the same 2.4-GHz channel on every access point.

questionText: Consider the frequency of an RF signal used in Wi-Fi communication. Which of the following statements are correct?
explanation: Wi-Fi devices can use frequencies that are in the 5-GHz band. IEEE 802.11a devices use the 5-GHz band, while 802.11g devices must use the 2.4-GHz band. Therefore, 802.11a frequencies are higher than 802.11g. A 5-GHz signal oscillates at 5 billion cycles per second, not 5 million. The frequency of a signal is related to a channel number; increasing frequencies correlate to increasing channel numbers.

answerChoices.Text: The signal can have a frequency around 5 Gigahertz.
A 5-GHz signal oscillates at 5 million cycles per second.
The signal frequency is not related to a channel number.
The frequencies used by 802.11a devices are higher than those used by 802.11g devices.

questionText: When a wireless frame is sent to an AP, which address is used as the Layer 2 destination address?
explanation: The BSSID is used as the destination MAC address because the frame is destined for the AP. It would not make sense to use the sender’s own MAC address as the destination. The sending device’s IP address cannot be used either because the Layer 2 destination address in the frame must be in the format of a MAC address. The AP’s Ethernet MAC address should not be used because it represents the address of the wired port and not the wireless radio.

questionText: Which of the following are the main frequency bands used for wireless LAN communications?
explanation: The main frequency bands are currently termed the 2.4 GHz, 5 GHz, and 6 GHz bands.

questionText: Usable RF signals tend to propagate farther and penetrate walls better in which one of the following frequency bands?
explanation: RF signals at lower frequencies tend to be useful at greater distances. They also can penetrate indoor walls and objects better than signals at higher frequencies.

answerChoices.Text: RF signals behave the same in any frequency band

questionText: Which one of the following statements correctly describes a wireless device using passive scanning?
explanation: When a wireless device uses passive scanning, it scans each channel and listens for any beacon frames that are received. The beacons contain information about the AP and the WLAN being used.

answerChoices.Text: Passive scanning is used to discover other wireless devices that are nearby.
Passive scanning is used to discover when a channel is idle so that the device can transmit.
Passive scanning is used to discover APs that are within range by transmitting Probe Request frames and listening for Probe Response frames in return.
Passive scanning is used to discover APs that are within range by listening for their beacon frames.

questionText: What are some of the wireless LAN controller (WLC) capabilities?
explanation: All of the responses are correct. A WLC is a centralized management that will give you much more information on the APs and the configurations than just the APs themselves.

answerChoices.Text: Dynamic RF management to assign channels to APs
RF monitoring to gather information about the channel
Ease of deployment by programming all RF policies and wireless LAN policies on all APs

questionText: In a split-MAC wireless architecture, a CAPWAP tunnel terminates on which of the following?
explanation: CAPWAP tunnels extend between lightweight APs and wireless LAN controllers because the AP functions are split between the two. An autonomous AP does not use CAPWAP tunnels at all. As well, end-user wireless devices do not participate in CAPWAP tunnels because lightweight APs serve as the nearest entry point into a CAPWAP tunnel toward a WLC.

questionText: An EWC refers to which of the following?
explanation: An embedded wireless controller (EWC) is a small-scale WLC that exists as code running on a normal AP platform.

answerChoices.Text: A controller that is embedded in a normal AP
A client that builds an external wireless connection to a third-party AP
A new generation of wireless controller with enhanced capabilities
The European Wireless Consortium that certifies Wi-Fi compatibility

questionText: Which of the following wireless controller deployment models supports the least number of APs?
explanation: The EWC model supports the least number of APs (100) because the WLC function runs on a normal lightweight AP, sharing the AP’s resources between AP and WLC operations. Distributed is the next most capable (250 APs), followed by Cloud (6000 APs) and Unified (6000 APs).

questionText: In a split-MAC architecture, real-time functions such as encryption are handled in which of the following network entities?
explanation: A split-MAC architecture splits up traditional AP functions such that a WLC handles non-real-time management functions, while a lightweight AP handles real-time functions like encryption. Network switches are not involved in the split-MAC architecture; instead, they transport data between the AP and WLC.

questionText: In a cloud-based WLC deployment, where the controller is located in a public cloud, the APs should be configured to operate in which one of the following modes?
explanation: The FlexConnect mode should be used because of the potential distance between the controller and the APs that are joined to it. The CAPWAP tunnels to the APs could go down in case of a connectivity failure, and FlexConnect would enable local wireless operations to continue.

questionText: Which one of the following controller deployments usually supports the least number of APs per WLC?
explanation: An embedded wireless controller (EWC) is generally the smallest-scale WLC deployment model. Because it runs on normal AP hardware, its performance and resources are relatively limited.

questionText: Which of the following is the normal operating mode of a Cisco lightweight AP?
explanation: Cisco lightweight APs normally operate in the Local mode, supporting regular WLANs, BSSs, split-MAC, and CAPWAP tunnels, plus providing network connectivity to wireless devices. Monitor mode is used to monitor channels, detect intrusion events and rogue devices, and help measure the location of devices. Normal and Regular are not legitimate mode names.

questionText: Which of the following statements is correct concerning a unified WLC deployment model?
explanation: A unified or centralized deployment model places a WLC in a central location. That enables the WLC to control and manage all APs, as well as handle CAPWAP tunnels from all APs. CAPWAP tunnels do not extend from access layer switches. WLCs are not positioned at access layer switches in a unified or centralized deployment. Centralized WLCs are designed to handle all or a majority of the APs in the campus, not only a small portion.

answerChoices.Text: CAPWAP tunnels extend from access layer switches to all APs.
CAPWAP tunnels extend from all APs to a centrally located WLC.
WLCs are positioned at each access layer switch.
A small portion of the total number of APs is managed by a centrally located WLC.

questionText: In a split-MAC wireless architecture, the traditional autonomous AP functions are split between which of the following entities?
explanation: The split-MAC architecture splits or distributes traditional AP functions between a lightweight AP and a wireless LAN controller. Wireless user devices are not involved in split-MAC at all. RADIUS servers can integrate with a wireless network to provide security functions like authentication, authorization, and accounting, but cannot become part of a split-MAC wireless architecture.

questionText: Suppose several cloud managed APs are deployed in a cloud-based architecture. Which of the following are correct statements about the control and data planes involved in the wireless network?
explanation: In a cloud-based architecture, such as one built with Cisco Meraki APs, the control plane extends from the APs to the cloud. In addition, the data plane extends from the wireless users to the APs.

answerChoices.Text: The data plane extends from the wireless users to the Internet cloud, where the APs are managed.
The control plane extends from the APs to the Internet cloud, where the APs are managed.
The data plane extends from the wireless users to the cloud-managed AP.
The control plane extends from the wireless users to the cloud-managed AP.

questionText: Which AP modes allow an AP to continue operating and forwarding traffic if a WLC or the path to a WLC is unavailable ?
explanation: By definition, autonomous mode allows an AP to function without a WLC at all. FlexConnect mode also maintains AP functionality, although only local traffic can be forwarded in a remote site environment. SE-Connect mode still requires a functioning WLC to work with the AP. An AP in Local mode cannot function without a functioning WLC.

questionText: What does CAPWAP mean?
explanation: CAPWAP means the Control and Provisioning of Wireless Access Points.

answerChoices.Text: Configuring and Provisioning of Wireless Access Points
Control and Provisioning of Wireless Access Points
Control and Policing of Wireless Access Points
Configuring and Policing of Wireless Access Points

questionText: Which two Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) deployment models provide the best scalability to large deployments?
explanation: Two of the WLC deployment models, centralized and cloud, provide the most sclability, with the centralized model using a stand-alone WLC and the cloud model running the WLC in a public or private cloud data center. The distributed model uses relatively smaller WLCs distributed throughout a campus network, while EWC runs the WLC software on a physical AP. Both the distributed and EWC models support smaller environments.
comments: Which two Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) deployment models provide the best scalability to large deployments?

questionText: Suppose a Cisco lightweight AP is deployed at a remote site so that it can provide local network connectivity in case the site loses its link back to the main site. Which of the following AP modes should be used?
explanation: FlexConnect mode is often used at remote sites to enable local switching at the AP in case the link between the main and remote sites is lost. If the remote site AP is running in Local mode, providing normal AP functions, its CAPWAP tunnels back to the main site; WLC would get dropped when the remote link was lost. SE-Connect mode is used to turn the AP into a dedicated spectrum analyzer, rather than a normally functioning AP. Finally, Remote mode is not a legitimate mode name.

questionText: Which one of the following is a main difference between FlexConnect and OfficeExtend?
explanation: By definition, an OfficeExtend AP will protect both control and user data by passing them over CAPWAP tunnels that use DTLS encryption. FlexConnect can protect user data with DTLS, but only if it is explicitly configured to do so.

answerChoices.Text: FlexConnect requires a WLC, while OfficeExtend does not.
OfficeExtend and FlexConnect are different names for the same feature.
Data traffic is always protected with OfficeExtend but not always with FlexConnect.
FlexConnect uses CAPWAP tunnels, while OfficeExtend uses GRE tunnels.

questionText: What is the maximum number of APs supported at a remote site by an OfficeExtend AP?
explanation: An OfficeExtend AP is designed to support a single AP (itself) in a remote worker’s office.

questionText: When a FlexConnect AP is running in connected mode, which one of the following statements is correct?
explanation: A FlexConnect AP runs in connected mode as long as it has connectivity to its controller. All wireless traffic passes over the CAPWAP tunnel to and from the controller. If connectivity to the controller is lost due to a WAN link or similar failure, the FlexConnect AP will automatically move to standalone mode.

answerChoices.Text: All wireless traffic is passed over the CAPWAP tunnel to and from the controller
Only wireless traffic destined to the AP’s local network passes over the CAPWAP tunnel
The AP connects its CAPWAP tunnel to another FlexConnect AP
The AP cannot contact its controller

questionText: If a WLC is positioned so that it connects into or near the core layer of a network, which type of wireless architecture is implied?
explanation: If the WLC is positioned near the core or center of the network, a centralized or unified deployment has been used. An autonomous architecture is not correct because it would not require a WLC at all. An embedded architecture has a WLC that is embedded within a network switch, usually in the access layer. Mobility express positions the WLC function within the actual APs.

questionText: A wireless network is to be built from Cisco APs, all in autonomous mode. Which of the following things is necessary for the wireless network to support three SSIDs that are mapped to three corresponding VLANs?
explanation: Each autonomous AP will require a trunk link to connect it to the wired network infrastructure. The trunk link is necessary to extend multiple VLANs to the AP, where VLANs will be mapped to WLANs. This is not possible with access links, where all traffic is carried over a single VLAN. Access links would be required for lightweight APs that partner with WLCs, but that is not the design presented here. A CAPWAP tunnel would be necessary from a WLC to each lightweight AP, but not to autonomous APs.

answerChoices.Text: An access link to each AP
A trunk link to each AP
A CAPWAP tunnel to each AP
This network design cannot carry multiple VLANs over wireless.

questionText: Which one of the following wireless deployments requires an AP but never a WLC?
explanation: By definition, an autonomous AP can stand alone without requiring any connection or assistance from a wireless LAN controller. A centralized deployment is based on a WLC supporting many APs. FlexConnect is an AP mode that requires a controller, but not at all times. Even though an embedded wireless controller (EWC) runs on an AP, that AP must still join itself to the controller instance that it is hosting.

questionText: Which one of the following statements is correct regarding a distributed WLC deployment?
explanation: A distributed deployment uses multiple controllers that are located throughout the network. In effect, the wireless load is distributed across the controllers. In contrast, any answer involving dividing wireless functions between an AP and a controller falls under the split-MAC architecture.

answerChoices.Text: Wireless functions are divided or split across the controller and its APs
The wireless MAC layer is distributed between an AP and a controller
FlexConnect must be used to distribute wireless connectivity if CAPWAP tunnels go down
Multiple smaller controllers are located throughout the network

questionText: Which of the following WLC interfaces or ports should be used to make a connection between a VLAN and a WLAN?
explanation: WLC dynamic interfaces are used to make a logical connection between a wired VLAN and a WLAN. On an IOS-XE WLC, the dynamic interface is simply the respective VLAN itself.  Distribution system ports connect the WLC to the physical network where VLANs exist, while the WLC touches wireless users through its APs and WLANs. The management interface is used for only WLC management traffic. The service port is used for out-of-band management, and the virtual interface is used to relay client mobility functions like DHCP and web authentication.

questionText: To build a new WLAN on an IOS-XE controller, you have already defined a WLAN profile that contains the SSID string, frequency band, and security settings for WPA2-PSK. Which one of the following parameters must you also configure in a policy profile before the new WLAN can become fully operational?
explanation: The problem says that you have already configured the WLAN profile, which contains all the necessary parameters to define the WLAN’s operation. Any RF settings, such as transmit power, channel numbers, and supported data rates, can all be determined by default profiles that are preconfigured. The one thing missing is a way to map the new wireless LAN to a wired VLAN. Therefore, you would need to configure the VLAN ID that is contained in the policy profile. Then the WLAN and policy profiles would need to be applied to the relevant APs in the form of a policy tag.

questionText: Suppose you need to connect two new Cisco APs to a switched network. One is an autonomous AP, the other a lightweight AP. The APs will be used to provide four WLANs that map to four VLANs. Which of the following correctly describes the wired network link that connects to the autonomous and lightweight APs, respectively?
explanation: The autonomous AP will need a wired link configured in trunking mode so that all four VLANs can be carried over the single link. The lightweight AP needs its wired connection configured in access mode. The same four VLANs will be available at the AP, but they will be carried between the WLC and AP over CAPWAP tunnels.

questionText: Which one of the following is a type of traffic that does not terminate on an IOS-XE controller’s wireless management interface?
explanation: The WMI is used to terminate many different types of management traffic, such as CAPWAP tunnels, GUI and SSH sessions to the WLC, SNMP, NTP, syslog, and so on. The VLANs that map to wireless client traffic pass over Layer 2 dynamic controller interfaces and do not terminate on the WMI.

questionText: Suppose that an AP is joined to an IOS-XE controller. You need to configure a new WLAN, its SSID, and a supported security method. Which of the following tags will you need to configure to set the necessary parameters?
explanation: The SSID and security settings are contained in a WLAN profile, which is mapped to a policy tag. You would also need to configure the VLAN number that the WLAN will map to, which is contained in a policy profile, also mapped to the policy tag.

questionText: To connect a Cisco wireless LAN controller to a wired network, which of the following would you use? Assume that this connection will carry traffic to and from APs.
explanation: The distribution system ports on a WLC are used to connect to the switched network infrastructure and carry data to and from APs. The console port is not used because it is a serial connection dedicated to WLC management. The service port is a network connection but is used only for out-of-band management. There is no AP data port; it is a fictitious concept.

questionText: Which of the following methods can you use to connect to an autonomous AP for management purposes?
explanation: An autonomous AP has a serial console port and a wired Ethernet port. Therefore, you can use a serial connection to the console. Once the AP has been configured with an IP address and has network connectivity, you can connect to it via Telnet, SSH, or HTTP/HTTPS.

questionText: Suppose the distribution system ports on an AireOS WLC are configured as a LAG. The switch ports where the WLC connects are also configured as trunk links that are bundled as a single logical EtherChannel using LACP. You notice that data is not passing across the links as expected. Which of the following would likely be the cause of the problem?
explanation: The AireOS WLC does not support any form of EtherChannel negotiation, so the switch ports should be configured for unconditional EtherChannel operation. The root cause of the problem is that the switch has been configured to expect LACP negotiation from the WLC before the EtherChannel will come up, but the WLC does not support it. For the best link redundancy and load balancing, all of the WLC distribution system ports should be configured in LAG mode, as the question text described. (In contrast, an IOS-XE based WLC does support LACP negotiation if the switch ports are configured to use it.)

answerChoices.Text: The switch ports should be configured for access mode only.
The switch ports should be configured to use PAgP to negotiate the EtherChannel.
The switch ports should be configured to operate as an EtherChannel unconditionally, with no negotiation.
Nothing is wrong with the switch; the WLC ports should not be configured in LAG mode.

questionText: Which one of the following statements is true about the dynamic interfaces (where the controller touches VLANs) of a wireless controller based on the IOS-XE platform?
explanation: An IOS-XE controller does need to interface with each wired VLAN, which is done through Layer 2–only operations. You cannot configure an IP address on its dynamic interfaces.

answerChoices.Text: Each dynamic interface needs an IP address configured
Each dynamic interface must be configured as an SVI
Each dynamic interface is Layer 2 only
An IOS-XE controller does not need to connect directly to any VLANs, only wireless LANs

questionText: Which of these ports does a WLC typically use to forward user traffic?
Which of the following protocols normally pass through the management interface on a WLC?
explanation: All management traffic to and from the WLC passes through the management interface. This can include SSH and HTTP/HTTPS sessions to the WLC GUI, SNMP, NTP, syslog, and RADIUS authentication, as well as CAPWAP data to and from all APs that are joined to the WLC. The management interface is not used for actual wireless user data passing to and from wired VLANs; that traffic passes over the dynamic or distribution system interfaces instead.

answerChoices.Text: HTTPS sessions to the WLC GUI
Wireless user data to and from a VLAN
CAPWAP tunnel traffic to and from APs
RADIUS exchanges for wireless user authentication

questionText: When configuring a wireless LAN from an AireOS WLC, you create a dynamic interface and a wireless LAN. Which answers identify the correct configuration area where you configure the stated parameters? (Choose three answers.)
explanation:
The dynamic interface and WLAN configurations in an AireOS WLC define the settings for a LAN's wired (dynamic interface) and wireless (WLAN) sides. The dynamic interface creation page gives input fields for:

•    A dynamic interface name
•    The numeric VLAN ID used on the wired network (the distribution system)

The wireless LAN creation page allows for the definition of:

•    The wireless LAN profile name
•    The SSID
•    A numeric WLAN ID (1-512)

To connect the parameters together, the WLAN configuration page has a field that references the dynamic interface name.

Of the various answers, one correct answer notes that you must configure the VLAN ID on the dynamic interface creation page. The other two correct answers list settings made on the WLAN creation page: the WLAN ID and the SSID.
comments: Formerly 200301-WO-v1-1-app-004 in the 2023 Exam Updates question batch.

answerChoices.Text: VLAN ID on the dynamic interface creation page
VLAN ID on the WLAN creation page
WLAN ID on the dynamic interface creation page
WLAN ID on the WLAN creation page
SSID on the dynamic interface creation page
SSID on the WLAN creation page

questionText: By default, how many clients will a wireless controller allow to connect to a single AP radio?
explanation: By default, a WLC will allow 200 clients to connect to a single AP radio.

questionText: Suppose you are configuring a new WLAN for your network and need to specify the SSID string for it. How many characters can you enter in the SSID string?
explanation: The SSID string can contain 1 to 32 ASCII characters. Spaces and other printable special characters are allowed.

questionText: Suppose a Cisco WLC has one service port, one redundancy port, four distribution system ports, and one console port. To gain the most advantage out of the four distribution system ports with load balancing and redundancy, which of the following would be the best strategy?
explanation: Because the WLC has four distribution system ports, they should be configured as a single logical LAG (link aggregation group). Distribution system ports should also always be configured as trunk links so that multiple VLANs can be mapped to WLANs on the WLC.

answerChoices.Text: Configure the distribution ports individually as access links.
Configure the distribution ports as a trunk link LAG.
Configure the distribution ports individually as trunk links.
Configure the distribution ports as an access link LAG.

questionText: By default, a wireless LAN controller will not allow ____________ traffic initiated from a WLAN?
explanation: As a default security measure, a wireless LAN controller will not allow management traffic to itself when initiated from a WLAN.

questionText:
Suppose you are preparing to deploy a new wireless LAN in your network. The APs are all joined to a single IOS-XE controller. You have carefully configured the WLAN and policy profiles with the new WLAN’s SSID, security, and the correct VLAN number. Then you mapped those profiles to a policy tag called Main_policy_tag. You made sure the new WLAN was enabled and that it would be broadcast. You also enabled the 2.4 and 5 GHz bands for the WLAN. You feel comfortable that any other parameters related to AP operation and RF settings will be inherited from the default profiles that come preconfigured on the controller. 

For some reason, the new WLAN does not seem to be working—no users can pick up the new SSID from it. Which one of the following is most likely the step you have forgotten to perform?
explanation: From the problem description, it sounds like you did everything correctly. You built the WLAN and policy profiles for the new WLAN, made sure the WLAN was enabled and used on the correct frequency bands, and made sure the SSID would be broadcast so clients could discover it. However, all the work you put into configuring the profiles were never actually used by the APs. That’s because you must have forgotten to apply the profile tag to the APs so they could pick up the new WLAN configuration.

answerChoices.Text: The default supported data rates are incorrect after all.
You should have rebooted all the APs so they would pick up the new WLAN configuration.
None of the wireless users were given the new WLAN’s pre-shared key.
You should have applied the policy tag to the APs.
You did everything right, so this must be due to a controller bug.

questionText: Suppose you need to configure a new WLAN with an SSID called Internal-Staff. The WLAN should support users using WPA2-Personal. Refer to the exhibit of the WLC GUI and decide which of the following actions should be taken to accomplish the goal.
explanation: To configure a WLAN that uses WPA2-Personal only, you would need to check the boxes next to WPA2 Policy, WPA2 Encryption AES, and PSK. Remember that -Personal denotes PSK authentication, whereas -Enterprise denotes 802.1x and EAP. You would not need to change the drop-down choice of WPA+WPA2 because that is the only option that allows WPA2. You should not check the boxes next to WPA Policy or WPA Encryption AES (or TKIP) because you want WPA to be disabled completely.

answerChoices.Text: In the Layer 2 Security drop-down menu, select WPA2 only instead of WPA+WPA2.
Check the box next to WPA Policy.
Check the AES box next to WPA Encryption.
Check the box next to WPA2 Policy.
Check the AES box next to WPA2 Encryption.
Check the Enable box next to 802.1X.
Check the Enable box next to PSK.

questionText: Which of the following statements correctly describe an AireOS WLC interfaces and ports?
explanation: On an AireOS WLC, ports are physical connections to an external wired network, while AireOS WLC interfaces are logical connections that exist internally.

answerChoices.Text: Ports are physical connections to a wired network.
Ports are logical connections within a WLC.

Interfaces are logical connections within a WLC.

questionText: When configuring a distribution system port on a WLC, which of the following statements are correct?
explanation: The link between the WLC and a switch must be configured as an 802.1Q trunk link. An AireOS WLC does not negotiate the 802.1Q trunk with the switch, so the link must be configured for unconditional 802.1Q trunk mode. An IOS-XE WLC can participate in LACP negotiation, if the WLC and switch are configured to do so.

answerChoices.Text: The port should be connected to a switch port in access mode.
The port should be connected to a switch port in trunking mode.
An IOS-XE WLC must use an unconditional 802.1Q trunk link with the connected switch.
An IOS-XE WLC can negotiate with the connected switch to bring up an 802.1Q trunk link if configured to do so.
An AireOS WLC can negotiate with the connected switch to bring up an 802.1Q trunk link if configured to do so.

questionText: What is the default session timeout that a controller enforces on wireless clients that connect to a WLAN?
explanation: By default, clients are limited to a session timeout of 1800 seconds (30 minutes). You can configure the session timeout to be a value from 0 (no timeout) to 86400 seconds; if 802.1x is in use, the minimum timout is 300 seconds.

questionText: How many IP addresses do you need to configure on a WLC based on the IOS-XE platform?
explanation: An IOS-XE controller needs only one IP address for its wireless management interface (WMI).

answerChoices.Text: It depends on how many VLANs the controller needs to map to WLANs

questionText: Which of the following things must be identified when configuring a new secure WLAN on a WLC?
explanation: A new WLAN must be configured with an SSID string, the appropriate dynamic interface, and the WPA version. Remember that the dynamic interface is used to logically map a VLAN to a WLAN. The WLAN configuration does not define the BSSID; that is determined by each AP and the WLAN it offers. In addition, you cannot specify specific channel numbers to use on the WLAN. Channels can be configured for a band or an RF profile as part of more advanced wireless functions on the WLC GUI.

questionText: When you are configuring a wireless LAN on a WLC, you should be aware of the maximum number of WLANs supported. Which of the following correctly identifies the maximum number of WLANs that can be configured and the maximum number that can be active on an AP, respectively?
explanation: You can configure a maximum of 512 WLANs on a Cisco WLC, but only up to 16 of them can be active on an AP. Remember to keep the number of active WLANs on an AP to a minimum because each WLAN adds overhead with its periodic beacon advertisements and user traffic. The more active WLANs you have, the higher the channel utilization will likely be.

questionText: The AP in the figure supports three separate wireless virtual LANs. What type of link needs to be used between the AP and the LAN switch if the AP is part of a split-MAC architecture?
explanation:
Because the AP is part of a split-MAC architecture, so it must join with a WLC. Regardless of the number of VLANs to support on the wireless side, the AP requires only an access mode switch port. The multiple VLANs are carried over a CAPWAP tunnel between the AP and WLC, so no trunk port is needed. 

The switch would not use a routed port because the AP does not act as a layer 3 device. A WLC port is not a type of switch port at all, so it is incorrect too.

questionText: An enterprise uses a WLC running AireOS. Which WLAN settings in the WLC use the same data format and have the same maximum length?
explanation:
The AireOS WLC provides a place to configure the WLAN profile name and the SSID on the same page (the WLAN creation page.) In fact, after configuring the profile name, WLC defaults to set the SSID to the same value. They are both text values with a max length of 32 characters.

Of the other fields in the answers, the VLAN ID and WLAN ID use numeric values but represent different concepts with different value ranges. The WLC uses the WLAN ID as an internal number for wireless LANs, supporting values from 1-512. The VLAN ID must match the VLAN ID used in the distribution system (the wired network), with WLC supporting values 1-1001 and 1007-4094.

Finally, the dynamic interface name is a text name that does not match any other listed fields.
comments: Formerly 200301-WO-v1-2-app-001-1 from the 2023 Exam Updates questions batch.

questionText: The figure shows three switch ports with typical cabling with IP phones. One port connects an old Cisco phone, another a new Cisco phone, and another a non-Cisco phone. Which answers describe working methods for the phone to learn what VLAN ID to use as the voice VLAN for the phone’s traffic?
explanation:
LAN switches dynamically inform attached IP phones what VLAN ID to use for the phone’s traffic on the pseudo-trunk between the switch and the phone. The original Cisco IP phones supported only Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) to declare the VLAN ID to the phone. Newer Cisco phones now support the standards-based LLDP-MED protocol for the same purpose – although they also support CDP. Non-Cisco phones never used the Cisco-proprietary CDP for learning phone settings, preferring LLDP from their earliest days.

As for the answers that mention static settings, the phones do not use a static setting for the voice VLAN on the link. Instead, they use CDP or LLDP-MED to learn the VLAN ID dynamically.
comments: Formerly 200301-WO-v2-1-app-003 from the 2023 exam updates question batcnh.

answerChoices.Text: On port G1/0/1, via static settings (phone configuration)
On port G1/0/2, via static settings (phone configuration)

questionText: Comparing LLDP to LLDP-MED, which answers make a claim that applies to LLDP-MED but not LLDP? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
The LLDP standard has used type-length-value (TLV) data structures since its original definition. For instance, the original LLDP standard defined TLVs that allow one device to inform a neighboring device about the first device’s name and port numbers used.

Using TLVs allows for easy future expansion of LLDP. LLDP Media Endpoint Discovery (LLDP-MED) refers to a set of endpoint-focused TLVs. LLDP-MED includes the TLVs that enable switches to inform an attached IP phone what voice VLAN ID to use on the link. As another example, LLDP TLVs support the IEEE Power over Ethernet (PoE) standards so that the powered device (PD) can use LLDP-MED to inform the attached switch of its power needs.
comments: Formerly 200301-WO-v2-2-app-003 from the 2023 Exam Updates question batch.

answerChoices.Text: Used to inform IP phones what voice VLAN to use on a link
Used to inform neighboring networking devices of local device facts, like port numbers
Used to inform a switch of an endpoint’s electrical power needs

questionText: A junior network engineer configured the CDP timer to be 180 seconds and the CDP holdtime timer to be 60 seconds. What is the outcome of this configuration?
explanation:
By default, CDP has a timer of 60 seconds, which means it sends a message to its neighbors every minute. CDP also has a holdtime timer that is 180 seconds by default. This holdtime timer is how long the device waits before removing the CDP neighbor information in the CDP table.

	The question has the timer values flipped from the default. The timer value is set to 180 and the holdtime timer is set to 60. Because of these values, there will not be enough time until the next CDP message is received before the holdtime timer is tripped, causing the CDP neighbor information to be flushed out of the CDP table before it’s even complete.

answerChoices.Text: Normal operation, because these are the default timers for CDP
Normal operation with non-default timers, with CDP neighbors up
No CDP neighbors, because the timer exceeds the holdtime timer
No CDP neighbors, because non-default timers are configured

questionText: What is the default aging time for MAC table entries that have not been used?
explanation: A switch will remove entries that have not been used for 300 seconds.

questionText: What will a switch compare in its MAC table to be able to forward a frame?
explanation: A switch will compare the destination MAC address of the frame to its MAC table to decide whether it should forward the frame or simply ignore it. A switch will not look at the IP address (layer 3) information to forward the frame. It cares about Layer 2 information, which is the MAC address.

questionText: How does a switch build its MAC address table?
explanation: A switch will build its MAC address table by listening to incoming frames and comparing the source MAC address to its address table. If the source MAC is not seen in the table, an entry will be added that will map the MAC address to the port. The switch will not examine the outgoing frames to build its MAC address table.

answerChoices.Text: By listening to outgoing frames and examining the source MAC address
By listening to incoming frames and examining the destination MAC address
By listening to incoming frames and examining the source MAC address
By listening to outgoing frames and examining the destination MAC address

questionText: Consider the messages sent when host PC1 pings PC4's IP address. Consider the messages that hold the ICMP Echo Request (sent by PC1) and Reply (sent by PC4), including the Ethernet header, IP header, and ICMP header. Which answers are accurate about those messages given the detail shown in the figure?
explanation:
In this example, PC1 and PC4 reside in different subnets, with one router between them. As a result, the router de-encapsulates the IP packet (holding the ICMP message) from the Ethernet frame, discarding the old Ethernet header and trailer - and then adding a new Ethernet header and trailer. Each frame uses a destination MAC address of a device on the same LAN or broadcast domain. 

Considering an ICMP Echo message sent by PC1 to PC4, the frame encapsulating the ICMP Request message uses:



	The IP header shows PC1's IPv4 address as the source and PC4's IPv4 address as the destination.
	The Ethernet header of the frame, as sent by PC1, includes a source MAC of  PC1's MAC and a destination MAC of R1-Gi0/0's MAC.
	The Ethernet header of the frame after the router routes the packet (including de-encapsulation and re-encapsulation) shows a source MAC of R1-Gi0/1's MAC and PC4's MAC address as the destination.  



In the reverse direction, with PC4 sending an ICMP Echo Reply:


	The IP header shows PC4's IPv4 address as the source and PC1's IPv4 address as the destination.
	The Ethernet header of the frame sent by PC4 shows PC4's MAC address as the source and R1-Gi0/1's MAC as the destination.
	The Ethernet header of the frame after the router routes the packet (including de-encapsulation and re-encapsulation) shows the R1-Gi0/0's MAC as the source and PC1's MAC address as the destination.


If you apply all these facts to the various answers, you can rule in and rule out each correct and incorrect answer, respectively.

questionText: After power on, a frame arrives at a switch. The switch had not yet learned the source MAC address of that frame. Which actions must the switch take in this case?

questionText: The MAC address table will hold which pieces of information?
explanation: When a MAC address is learned on a port, the switch will update its MAC address table to map the MAC address learned along with the correspondingswitch port. The source IP, destination IP addresses and tranport port numbers will not be mapped in the MAC table.

questionText: Based on the information shown in the exhibit, what can be said of the configuration of the Gi0/4 interface?
explanation: Most Ethernet interfaces support both automatic configuration via autonegotiation (802.3u) and the manual configuration of both interface speed and duplex. The Gi0/4 interface shown displays “half” and “100”; if autonegotiation had been used, it would display "a-half" and "a-100". This means that both the interface speed and duplex have been manually configured with the speed 100 and duplex half commands, respectively.

questionText: The figure displays three PCs connected to a switch. All PC NICs support the highest speeds. questionText: Host B in the figure disables IEEE autonegotiation and manually sets its speed and duplex to 100/full. What setting will the switch use on the other end of the link?
explanation:
When one link partner (in this case, host B) fails to use IEEE auto-negotiation, and the other end attempts it (in this case, switch SW1), the switch can sense the speed, but it must choose a duplex setting based on a table of defaults. For the speed, the switch examines the electrical signals sent by host B and can discern the standard used by host B – and then use that same standard. Then, for the duplex, it uses this table:


	For 10 or 100 Mbps: Default to half duplex
	For higher speeds: Default to full duplex


In this case, the switch senses and uses 100 Mbps and chooses half duplex from the list of defaults. This scenario shows a classic case of duplex mismatch between the two endpoints.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit. Which of the following commands has been configured on the displayed switchport?
explanation: Two switch interface subcommands, shutdown and no shutdown, administratively enable or disables an interface (switchport). Cisco switches default to no shutdown, meaning all ports begin in an enabled state. The output lists the interface in an administratively down state, meaning someone configured the shutdown subcommand on the interface.

questionText: What are common LAN Layer 1 problem indicators?
explanation:
Collisions and late collisions can be due to mismatched settings such as duplex on either side of the connection. A late collision in a half-duplex environment could be due to physical cable lengths being longer than the standard permits.

	High-bandwidth utilization could be normal, based on the amount of traffic flowing through the network. Incorrect IP addressing would be a symptom of poor Layer 3 planning and implementation, and incorrect VLAN assignments would be poor Layer 2 implementation and/or planning.

questionText: The figure displays three PCs connected to a switch. All PC NICs support the highest speeds. Some PCs have power, and some have cables connecting them to the switch, but some have no power or no cable. The show interfaces status command lists both a speed and duplex column. Which answers accurately describe the output in those columns for the combined three interfaces? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
First, consider the three cases. On port G1/0/1, the PC has power, and a cable exists. As a result, the link works, and then autonegotiation works. However, on the other two links, a problem exists, so the link does not work. On G1/0/2, no cable exists, and on G1/0/3, the PC has no power. So, those links do not work, so no autonegotiation occurs.

Second, you must recall that the default settings for speed and duplex on switch interfaces cause them to use autonegotiation. As a result, the show interfaces status command, for interfaces in a down/down (notconnect) state, lists a status as if autonegotiation is yet to be done, using the word "auto" in each case. So, the output for G1/0/2 and G1/0/3 lists the speed and duplex as "auto."

For the working interface, G1/0/1, the output lists "a-1000" for the speed, meaning it autonegotiated to use 1000 Mbps. Similarly, the output shows "a-full" in the duplex heading, meaning it autonegotiated to use full duplex.

Three answers suggest values under the speed column for one interface only. The answer that includes "a-1000" is correct, as only interface G1/0/1 has that speed status value. Three answers suggest values under the duplex column for two interfaces. The answer listing "auto" is correct, as interfaces G1/0/2 and G1/0/3 would both list that value.

answerChoices.Text: Exactly one interface lists the speed as 1000
Exactly one interface lists the speed as auto
Exactly one interface lists the speed as a-1000
Exactly two interfaces list the duplex as auto
Exactly two interfaces list the duplex as a-full
Exactly two interfaces list the duplex as half

questionText: Refer to the diagram. Assuming autonegotiation is enabled, what would be the resulting speed and duplex of the link between the switch and Host A?
explanation: If both the host and the switch support 1000 Mbps speeds, then the resulting connection would use a speed of 1000 Mbps and a duplex of Full.

questionText: Refer to the diagram. If autonegotiation of the speed and duplex between Host B and the switch works, what would be the resulting speed and duplex?
Which Cisco IOS command can be used to display which VLANs are supported over a specific configured switch trunk?
explanation: Both the show interfaces trunk and the show interfaces interface switchport commands can be used to display the VLANs that are allowed over a trunk.

questionText: Which types of Layer 2 frames will be forwarded to all other ports in the same VLAN except for the port in which the frame was received?
explanation:
When a switch receives a frame destined for a unicast Layer 2 address, and the switch doesn’t have that unicast address in its MAC address table (it doesn’t know which port the address is connected to), the switch will err on the side of caution and forward the frame to all other ports in the same VLAN, based on the VLAN that the incoming frame belonged to. Broadcast frames will get the same treatment as the unknown unicast frame and be sent to all other ports in the same VLAN.

Unicast frames, which are in the switch’s MAC address table, will be forwarded only to the port within the same VLAN, where that destination address is connected to the switch. IPv4 and IPv6 refer to Layer 3 IP addresses and are not involved with the switch’s Layer 2 forwarding logic.

answerChoices.Text: Unicast frames whose destination MAC address is not currently in the MAC address table
Unicast frames whose destination MAC address is currently in the MAC address table

questionText: Refer to the exhibit and diagram; to make it possible for all traffic to pass between PC1’s LAN and PC2’s LAN, the link between SW1 and SW2 will be configured as a trunk. Which Cisco IOS command could be used on SW1’s Gi0/1 interface to force it to actively attempt to trunk with SW2?
explanation: Four different switchport modes can be configured: access, trunk, dynamic desirable, and dynamic auto. They are configured with the switchport mode {access | trunk | dynamic {desirable | auto} command. The switchport mode access and switchport mode trunk commands statically configure a switchport as an access or a trunking port, respectively. The switchport mode dynamic desirable and switchport mode dynamic auto commands are used to configure a switchport to dynamically form a trunk. A switchport in desirable mode will actively attempt to form a trunk, whereas the auto mode will not form a trunk unless connected to another device that is configured as either dynamic desirable or as static trunk .

questionText: Refer to the exhibit. The device that is located off SW1's G0/1 interface is complaining that it is unable to send any traffic. Which command would be used to fix this problem?
explanation: The output of the show vlan [brief] commands will display whether a VLAN has been individually disabled by displaying its status as “act/lshut.” To remedy this, the no shutdown command must be entered while in VLAN configuration mode for the specific VLAN (vlan 400).

questionText: Which command administratively disables trunking on a Cisco switch interface so the switch cannot use a trunking protocol? Note that all commands in the answers use interface configuration mode.
explanation:
The switchport mode access command tells the switch not to attempt to form a trunk dynamically and not to use trunking on the interface. The no switchport mode trunk command tells the switch to revert to the default setting for trunk negotiation. The default on most Cisco Catalyst switches is dynamic auto, which tells the switch to react to any received negotiation messages.

One incorrect answer mentions the no switchport mode trunk command, which tells the switch to revert to the default setting for trunk negotiation. The default on most Cisco access switches is switchport mode dynamic auto, which tells the switch to react to any received negotiation messages. So the switch port would negotiate trunking if the neighboring switch requested it.

Another incorrect answer lists the switchport access vlan x command. This command defines the VLAN to statically assign to the port if it acts as an access port, but the command does not prevent the switch from attempting to negotiate trunking on the port.

The remaining incorrect answers show commands that do not exist in Cisco switches.

questionText: A Cisco Catalyst LAN switch configuration creates VLANs, assigns access VLANs, and configures trunks. The switch hardware includes interfaces with interface IDs G1/0/1, G1/0/2, and so on, through G1/0/24. The exhibit lists output from the show vlan brief command. Which answers list facts that the output in the exhibit confirms? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
The answers come in pairs. Both pairs require you to know the logic IOS uses to decide which interfaces to list in the output from the command. In particular:

The command lists all interfaces with the interface's configured access VLAN, whether up or down, except for interfaces in an up/up (connect) state and operating as a VLAN trunk.

Examining the two answers about interface G1/0/8, the output lists that interface in the interface group for VLAN 3. That tells us the access VLAN configured for that interface (which confirms one correct answer.) However, G1/0/8 will appear in the output whether in a connected (up/up) or notconnect (down/down) state. So you cannot know the interface's state by seeing the interface in this command's output.

For the two answers that mention interface G1/0/17, note that the output does not list the interface. That means the interface currently operates as a trunk. That is, it has an operational state of trunking. The interface must therefore be working, making the one answer that mentions G1/0/17 correct and one incorrect.

answerChoices.Text: G1/0/8's configuration assigns it to access VLAN 3
G1/0/8 is in a connected (up/up) state
G1/0/17 is not in an up/up (connected) state
G1/0/17 is in an up/up (connected) state

questionText: Which of the following are characteristics of 802.1Q?
explanation:
This question examines the characteristics of 802.1Q, and also uses facts about the older proprietary ISL in the distractor answers. 802.1Q does:


	Add a header before sending a frame over a trunk.
	When adding a header, adds the header between the original frame’s source address and type fields (whereas ISL encapsulates the original frame).
	Uses a concept of a native VLAN, in which frames are not tagged - that is, no additional 802.1Q header is inserted (whereas ISL has no equivalent idea).
	Is defined by the IEEE 802.1 committee (while ISL is Cisco proprietary).
	Is supported by Cisco IP phones and all Ciosco switches (and many other switches today), while most Cisco switches no longer support ISL.

answerChoices.Text: Encapsulates a normal Ethernet frame before forwarding it over a trunk
Does not encapsulate a normal Ethernet frame before forwarding, but  instead inserts a header after the destination and source MAC addresses
Uses the concept of a native VLAN

questionText: The figure shows three ports connected first to a Cisco IP phone and then to a PC. The figure shows the VLANs intended for the phones (10) and the PCs (11). The exhibit shows the planned configuration for two ports. Which answers note the incorrect configuration line(s)?
explanation:
The keys to configuring voice ports include:


	Configure the port as an access port, even though it supports two VLANs and uses some trunking features.
	Configure the VLAN for data devices – the PCs – like you usually would, with the switchport access vlan vlan-id subcommand.
	Configure the voice VLAN with the switchport voice vlan vlan-id subcommand.


In this case, the configuration for port G1/0/2 is entirely correct, so the two answers that suggest errors in the G1/0/2 configuration are incorrect. Note that for G1/0/2, it configures the port as an access port (switchport mode access), it sets the data vlan to 11 (switchport access vlan 11), and the voice vlan to 10 (switchport voice vlan 10).

The correct answer – which identifies a configuration mistake – comes from interface G1/0/1. The interface needs a switchport access vlan subcommand, but as configured, it sets that VLAN (the data VLAN) to VLAN 10. The figure shows the data VLAN as VLAN 11.

The one incorrect answer that lists interface G1/0/1 suggests the switchport mode access command is in error. Instead, it is part of the working access port configuration for ports connecting to IP phones.

answerChoices.Text: The switchport access vlan 10 command on port G1/0/1
The switchport mode access command on port G1/0/1
The switchport access vlan 11 command on port G1/0/2
The switchport voice vlan 10 command on port G1/0/2

questionText: The figure shows three ports connected first to a Cisco IP phone and then to a PC. The figure shows the VLANs intended for the phones (10) and the PCs (11). The exhibit shows the planned configuration for two ports. Which answers note the incorrect configuration line(s)?
explanation:
The keys to configuring voice ports include:


	Configure the port as an access port, even though it supports two VLANs and uses some trunking features.
	Configure the VLAN for data devices – the PCs – like you usually would, with the switchport access vlan vlan-id subcommand.
	Configure the voice VLAN with the switchport access voice vlan vlan-id subcommand.


In this case, the configuration for port G1/0/1 is entirely correct, so the two answers that suggest errors in the G1/0/1 configuration are incorrect. Note that for G1/0/1, it configures the port as an access port (switchport mode access), it sets the data vlan to 11 (switchport access vlan 11), and the voice vlan to 10 (switchport access voice vlan 10).

The correct answer suggests that the switchport mode trunk command on port G1/0/2 has a problem. That command makes the port a trunk port. Even though ports connected to IP phones have some trunk-like behavior, the switches require them to be access ports that support only two VLANs. The correct command would instead be switchport mode access.

The one incorrect answer that lists interface G1/0/2 suggests an issue with the switchport access vlan 11 command. Instead, it is part of the working access port configuration, setting the correct data VLAN of 11.

answerChoices.Text: The switchport access vlan 10 command on port G1/0/1
The switchport mode access command on port G1/0/1
The switchport mode trunk command on port G1/0/2
The switchport access vlan 11 command on port G1/0/2

questionText: Two switches are connected using a crossover cable. Using the combinations of configurations for the switchport mode mode interface subcommand (one on each end of the crossover cable on each switch), which of the following are accurate?
explanation:
Because the desirable side will request the trunk, and the auto side will agree, dynamic desirable and dynamic auto will end up in a trunk being formed. Trunk and dynamic auto will end up in a trunk being formed. When configured as a trunk, DTP is still enabled and will request a trunk to the other side, which is configured as auto and will agree to the trunk.

	If one side is configured as a trunk and the other is configured as an access port, a trunk will not be negotiated on both sides, and there will be limited connectivity. If both sides are dynamic auto, a trunk will not be negotiated. If both switches are configured as access ports for a specific VLAN, that VLAN will be supported on that link.

answerChoices.Text: access and trunk would end up in a negotiated trunk.
dynamic auto and dynamic auto will end up in a dynamic trunk being negotiated.
dynamic desirable and dynamic auto will end up in a trunk being formed.
trunk and dynamic auto will end up in a trunk being formed.

questionText: One of the key differences between ISL and 802.1q is the concept of a native VLAN. Which of the following is true about the native VLAN and its use in ISL and 802.1Q?
explanation: ISL does not use a concept of a native VLAN at all. With 802.1q, frames in the native VLAN, or VLAN 1 are not tagged with an 802.1Q header at all. So, when a switch receives a frame in a port that is trunking, and that frame has no 802.1Q header, the receiving switch assumes the frame is part of that trunk's native VLAN.

answerChoices.Text: ISL does not encapsulate frames if they are a part of the native VLAN
802.1Q does not tag (add) a trunking header to frames if they are a part of the native VLAN
ISL encapsulates frames for the native VLAN as if they were in reserved VLAN 999
802.1Q tags frames for the native VLAN as if they were in reserved VLAN 999

questionText: An engineer intends to use the four TenGig interfaces on switch SW1, interfaces 1/1/1-4, as VLAN trunks. The exhibit shows the output from the show interfaces status command on the switch. Which answers provide an accurate interpretation of the data in the VLAN column? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
In the VLAN column, the show interfaces status command displays the access VLAN ID for ports operating as access ports and the word "trunk" for ports operating as trunks. That one statement sums up all you need to answer this question.

For the two answers about the number of ports operating as trunks, only two show the word "trunk," so two interfaces trunk (one correct answer). Of course, the answer suggesting four ports operate as a trunk is incorrect. 

The other correct answer mentions that one port uses access VLAN 100, as seen in the output. However, the output does not list the native VLAN, so the answer suggesting native VLAN 10 is incorrect.

answerChoices.Text: All four interfaces currently operate as a trunk.
Two interfaces currently operate as a trunk.
One interface has been configured to use native VLAN 10.
One interface has been configured to use access VLAN 100.

questionText: The switches in the figure happen to use a default interface setting of switchport mode dynamic auto. However, the exhibit reveals that some interfaces have been configured with other settings. Which answers correctly state whether an interface will use trunking or not?

answerChoices.Text: The link between SW2 and SW4 will not trunk.
SW1’s fa0/2 interface will use trunking.
The link between SW1 and SW4 will trunk.

questionText: In this network, all switches are powered on, and all relevant VLANs have been configured correctly and are working. Based on the output in the exhibit, which of the following statements is true about switch SW2?
explanation: The show version command states that this switch has 24 FastEthernet and two Gigabit Ethernet interfaces. The show vlan brief command lists the two Gigabit interfaces, plus only 21 FastEthernet interfaces. This command omits interfaces when an interface is currently operating as a trunk. This command also omits a non-trunking interface if its assigned VLAN has been deleted (unconfigured), but the question states that all required VLANs have been configured and are working. From these facts, you can conclude that three interfaces (Fa0/22, 23, and 24) are trunking.

answerChoices.Text: Not enough information is provided to know which interfaces are trunking.

questionText: What is true about the command switchport nonegotiate?
explanation:
Cisco Catalyst switches use two related commands to turn DTP on and off on an interface. The switchport nonegotiate command disables DTP, while the no switchport nonegotiate command (the default setting) enables DTP. The question asks what happens with DTP disabled on a switch port.

If one switch configures to use dynamic desirable or dynamic auto, and the other disables DTP, the first switch will not trunk because it requires DTP messages to negotiate trunking. 

However, the link can trunk even if one or both switches disable DTP with the switchport nonegotiate command. For example, if both switches use the switchport mode trunk command, they will trunk, regardless of whether DTP is enabled or disabled.

For the incorrect answer that mentions routers, note that routers do not negotiate trunking with DTP, so they do not use this command.
comments: 3/28 - ok as is, 3/23 - query to Au if statement here applies. "The switchport switchport nonegotiate command, an interface subcommand, disables DTP (Dynamic Trunking Protocol) on an interface. Switches use DTP to negotiate with the neighboring device about whether to use VLAN trunking or not. So, this command prevents a switch port from trunking IF the port uses a trunking mode that dynamically negotiates trunking. However, using this command does allow trunking to work if the interface mode trunk command is being used, as that command allows a switch to trunk without using DTP to negotiate." 5/10 - query to Au

answerChoices.Text: If connected to a switch that uses dynamic desirable, the neighboring switch will not trunk.
Using this command prevents a switchport from being a trunk port.
It is used on a router to prevent VLAN hopping.
This will cause DTP packets to be sent, preventing a trunk from being negotiated.

questionText: The exhibit shows the output of a couple of show commands. Which of the following statements is true about the trunk shown in the exhibit?

answerChoices.Text: Traffic from VLANs 900 and 901 is not allowed to cross the fa0/1 trunk.
VLAN 3 traffic is not allowed to cross the fa0/1 trunk.
VLAN 3 traffic does not have an 802.1Q header as it crosses the fa0/1 trunk.
The switchport mode command, on the switch on the other end of port fa0/1, must have a setting of either dynamic desirable or trunk.
The switchport mode command, on the switch on the other end of port fa0/1, must have a setting of either dynamic desirable, dynamic auto, or trunk.
The switchport mode command, on the switch on the other end of port fa0/1, must have a setting of dynamic desirable.

questionText:
The figure shows a LAN topology. The switches function as desired with the current configuration, which includes configuration for the ports connected to the PCs (not shown) as access ports in VLAN 11. The exhibit shows the planned configuration for two ports. Later, someone else connects to switch SW2 and adds these configuration commands:


interface range gi1/0/1-24,te1/1/1-2
  switchport trunk native vlan 11


Which answer best describes the results of the new configuration? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
The question begins by describing working access ports in VLAN 11. It also references the exhibit, which shows a working VLAN trunk configuration that does not configure the native VLAN. As a result, the trunk uses default native VLAN 1.

The question then shows two additional commands which change the native VLAN setting on all switch SW2 ports shown in the figure (plus others) to VLAN 11. That creates an issue on the trunk. Switch SW1 uses the default native VLAN 1, while switch SW2 now uses native VLAN 11 per the new configuration. Mismatched native VLANs cause frames in the two VLANs on either side of the link to either (a) not flow across the trunk or (b) flow but hop (change) VLANs. Both are problems; the configuration should instead set the same native VLAN number on both ends of the trunk. So, the new configuration breaks the trunk.

The configuration also changes the native VLAN setting on switch SW2's ports connected to the PCs, specifically G1/0/4 through G1/0/6. Those ports, as stated in the question stem, are access ports. Therefore, the native VLAN setting does not impact those ports' operation, making one answer correct. One incorrect answer claims that the native VLAN setting on those ports causes a native VLAN mismatch on those ports, and it does not because those ports are not trunks.
comments: 6/1 - OK as-is, 5/24 - query to Au, CD-I1-3-10-003-1

answerChoices.Text: It causes a native VLAN mismatch on the trunk between switches.
It causes a native VLAN mismatch on the SW2 ports connected to PCs
It causes no issues on the SW2 ports connected to the PCs
It causes no issues on the trunk between the switches.

questionText: Based on the figure, what Cisco IOS command would be used on switch SW4 to correctly configure switchport Fa0/1 to be an access port in VLAN 30 ?
explanation: Per the diagram, PC3 is supposed to be placed into VLAN 30. To configure this, the switchport that connects to PC3 must be configured into VLAN 30; this is done with the switchport access vlan 30 command.

questionText: If spanning tree is disabled, what are the potential issues with a redundant Layer 2 network design?
explanation:
Without spanning tree, and if parallel Layer 2 paths exist, there would be loops. As a result, broadcast storms, duplicate frames, and MAC table flapping (where the switch is relearning the same MAC address but on different ports back and forth over and over again) would all be symptoms.

	There are no TTL mechanisms at Layer 2. IP addresses are a Layer 3 function and would not be caused from a Layer 2 loop.

questionText: Which of the following answers describes a method to remove the need for spanning tree in a two switch network?
explanation:
STP would not be needed if there were no redundant parallel Layer 2 paths in the network. One way of removing parallel paths is to make them into a single logical link, as with EtherChannel.

	If there were only two switches, and they had parallel paths, STP would be needed to prevent the Layer 2 loop. Rapid Spanning Tree is still spanning tree, and that alone would not remove the need for it. Parallel paths can be created over access or trunk ports, and that alone would not remove the need for spanning tree.

answerChoices.Text: No Layer 2 redundant paths in the network
Multiple Layer 2 paths, but only use two switches
Using EtherChannel to combine multiple parallel segments into one logical link
Using more trunks rather than access ports

questionText: Which layer of a campus network typically utilizes BPDU Filter?
explanation: BPDU Filter is most commonly used at the access layer, particularly on edge or access ports that connect to end devices such as servers, workstations, or other non-bridge devices. The core and distribution layers are used for extremely fast movement of frames/packets and interconnecting other switches within the campus network, respectively. These are not where typical users have access to plug in a rogue switch, although anything is possible. Finally, Layer 3 uses routing and therefore doesn’t use STP at all.

questionText: Which of the following are functions provided by Spanning Tree Protocol?
explanation:
By blocking on specific ports that would otherwise be parallel Layer 2 paths, STP prevents Layer 2 loops, thus preventing broadcast storms, preventing MAC table instability due to the a single-source Layer 2 address showing up on multiple different ports, and preventing multiple copies of a single frame from being forwarded (because spanning tree is blocking on enough ports to stop the forwarding of frames on parallel paths).

	STP does not use any TTL mechanism in a frame header (there is not one there); that is why it must do blocking on Layer 2 ports where an otherwise parallel path would be. STP performs blocking on Layer 2 ports, not Layer 3 ports.

answerChoices.Text: Uses TTL to control loops in the network
Places a Layer 3 port into blocking state if it is a parallel (redundant) path that would cause a loop
Prevents multiple copies of a single frame from being forwarded

questionText: In the figure, in VLAN 1, all switches have default STP settings, and all trunks are up and running at 100 Mbps. Which statements are true regarding the behavior of STP in this network, for VLAN 1, after the STP topology has stabilized?
explanation: With all default settings, the priorities tie. This means that the switch with the lowest MAC address (SW1) becomes root. Each of the other three switches has a direct connection to SW1, so those switches receive a Hello from SW1, cost 0. The interfaces on which those zero-cost Hellos were received are the switch’s root ports, which turns out to be fa0/1 on each switch in this example. Because SW4’s fa0/1 is its root port, SW4 will not forward Hellos out that port, and because it is already a root port, SW4’s fa0/1 cannot become a designated port.Only the root creates Hellos when the network is stable, so SW2 would never create Hellos. Rather, it updates and forwards the ones it receives from the root (SW1).

answerChoices.Text: SW4 will forward a Hello out its fa0/1 with cost 19.
SW1 will create Hello messages regularly based on its Hello timer.
SW2 will create Hello messages regularly based on its Hello timer.
SW4’s fa0/1 will become a designated port.
SW3's fa0/1 interface will be in a forwarding state.

questionText: In the figure, in VLAN 1, all switches have mostly default STP settings, and all trunks are up. The only nondefault setting is that the port cost of SW2’s fa0/1 interface has been changed to 1. Which statements are true regarding the behavior of STP in this network, for VLAN 1, when the STP topology has stabilized? (Refer to the exhibit for information related to the figure.)

So SW2’s root cost is 1, based on the sum of: (a) the 0 cost of the hello and (b) the interface cost of 1 for the interface in which the Hello was received. That F0/1 port happens to become SW2’s root port. So, SW2 forwards the Hello out its F0/3 and F0/4 ports, listing SW2’s cost, which is 1.

There is never a case in which a non-root switch can advertise a hello with cost 0, because the lowest STP interface cost is 1, and a non-root switch must be at least one outgoing interface away from the root"  11/28, 6/28 - query to Au, CD-I2-2-57-004-1
