SW2 sends a Hello to SW3, out SW2’s fa0/3, with cost 19.

questionText: On which switch would you always find a root port?
explanation:
Only nonroot switches have root ports.

	The root switch does not have any root ports for the VLAN it is the root of. A root switch has all forwarding ports (as could a nonroot switch if there were no redundant links). A root switch does not have blocking ports, but because it is the root it also does not have any root ports on it. Root switches and nonroot switches both could have designated ports, and the root switch would not have any root ports.

answerChoices.Text: Switch that does not have any blocking ports
Switch that has a designated port

questionText: PortFast enables you to set ports on your switch to be placed in a forwarding state once the host device is plugged in.  What Cisco feature enables you to detect switches or any other networking devices that could cause problems on links with PortFast enabled?
explanation: BPDU Guard will shutdown a port that receives a BPDU packet from another switch. Portfast moves a port to Forwarding state without waiting for the usual STP/RSTP steps, so adding BPDU Guard on the same ports helps prevent issues when a port with portfast happens to connect to another switch.

questionText: In a layer 2 switched LAN, all links are running at 100 Mbps. STP uses all default port cost configuration. Non-root switch SW2 receives a Hello on its root port, with that Hello listing a root cost of 38. If SW2 then forwards a Hello out some other port, what root cost will SW2 list in that Hello?

Refer to the exhibit; switch SW3 is receiving only two hello BPDUs, both of which identify the same root switch, received on the two interfaces listed. SW3 has no STP-related configuration commands. The hello received on Fa0/13 lists root cost 10, and the hello received on Gi0/1 lists root cost 20. Which of the following is true about STP on SW3?
explanation:
For a switch to determine its own root cost, the switch adds its received root cost (as advertised by neighbors) to the local switch's interfaces. In this case, while the advertised cost is lower for the Hello SW3 receives on its Fa0/13 interface (cost 10), SW3 must then add the cost of F0/13. So SW3's root cost out its F0/13 would be 29 (10 + 19). While the cost SW3 receives in the Hello coming in the GigabitEthernet link is 20, when SW3 adds the G0/1 cost to the link, SW3's root cost out its G0/1 would be 24 (20 + 4). Because of this, SW3 will choose its Gi0/1 link as its root port.

	Regarding G0/1 becoming the designated port, it will not, because G0/1 is the root port.

	Regarding whether SW3’s Fa0/13 will become a designated port, we know that SW3 is receiving a Hello on F0/13 with root cost 10. SW3 would advertise it's root cost as 24. The designated port is the port out which the least-cost Hello is advertised, so the other switch off SW3's F0/13 port would win the election, and SW3's F0/13 would not be the designated port.

answerChoices.Text: SW3 will choose Fa0/13 as its root port.
SW3 will choose Gi0/1 as its root port.
SW3’s Fa0/13 will become a designated port.
SW3’s Gi0/1 will become a designated port.

questionText: Assuming all default STP settings, which of SW3's ports will become its root port, and what will its root cost be?
explanation:
Using the default port costs, a Gigabit Ethernet port will have a cost of 4 and a Fast Ethernet port will have a cost of 19. SW3 will have two interfaces that can be used to forward traffic to the root switch (SW4): through its Gi0/1 interface via SW1, which results in a total cost of 8, or via its Fa0/2 interface, which results in a total cost of 19. It will select the option with the lowest cost, so it will select its Gi0/1 interface as its root port with a cost of 8.

Summarizing the competing potential root paths and their costs:


	SW3 G0/1 - SW1 G0/3  - 4 + 4 = 8
	SW3 G0/1 - SW1 G0/1 - SW2 G0/2  - 4 + 4 + 4 = 12
	SW3 F0/2  - 19

I think you were picking the higher cost path from SW3 to SW1 to SW2 and then SW4, which would be cost 12, and therefore not the least cost path."

That adds 4 more. That gives the correct root cost of 8. I’m wondering if for some reason you believe SW1’s root port would be its G0/1 port? Or that SW2 would be root? Anyway, I believe the question is correct as is."

questionText:
What is the correct order for the following steps in the spanning-tree algorithm?

	A: Elect a designated port for each segment.
	B: Elect a root port for each nonroot switch.
	C: Root ports and designated ports transition to the forwarding state.
	D: Elect a root bridge.
explanation:
The correct order is as follows:

	D: Elect a root bridge.
	B: Elect a root port for each nonroot bridge.
	A: Elect a designated port for each segment.
	C: Root ports and designated ports transition to the forwarding state.

questionText: Which of the following represents the total cost between the device forwarding a BPDU and the switch in STP that has the lowest BID?
explanation:
The STP cost between the switch that is advertising the STP BPDU and the root of STP is the sender’s root cost.

	Bridge IDs are just identifiers of devices in STP and by themselves do not represent cost. The hello timer is used in spanning tree and is controlled by the root switch, as is the forward delay timer.

questionText: RSTP serves as an improved protocol in comparison to the older STP. Which of the following answers lists a feature of RSTP that does not exist in STP?
explanation: RSTP uses the same rules as STP for choosing the root and choosing which ports serve as root port and designated port. Of the listed answers, the only answer that does not list the root switch election, or root port/designated port selection, is the answer that refers to the backup port role. That role was added by RSTP, and not in STP.

answerChoices.Text: The criteria used by a nonroot switch to choose its own root port
The criteria used by switches to elect a root switch
The criteria used by switches to determine a port to act in the backup port role
The criteria used by switches to determine the designated port on a segment

questionText: What is the name of the RSTP port state that replaces the STP disabled and blocking states?
explanation: When implementing the Rapid Spanning Tree Protocol (RSTP), one of the changes is that the previous disabled and blocking states are replaced by a single discarding state.

questionText: In the figure, the current STP state information is listed, with F for Forwarding and B for Blocking. SW1 is the current root. Assume that all STP parameters are using default values. Next, the network administrator configures a base priority value of 61440 on SW1. Assuming that SW2 wins the new root election, which of the following statements is true about STP convergence?
explanation: When the topology changes, if an interface that was blocking needs to  move to a forwarding state, it must spend Forward Delay (default 15  seconds) time in both listening and learning states. If an interface was  in a forwarding state, and it does not need to change to blocking, the  interface simply stays in a forwarding state.

questionText: The diagram of a small switched network, with all switches acting as layer 2 switches in VLAN 10. The diagram notes the switch chosen as root switch, with each root port noted with the letters RP and each designated port noted with the letters DP. All three switches use RSTP, and they might also have other RSTP configuration settings not noted in the question. Which of the following statements about RSTP states and roles in this network are true?
explanation:
The alternate port role in RSTP serves as an alternate root port. The only requirement for a non-root port to be an alternate root port is to receive Hellos that identify the same root switch as the Hello received on the root port. In this RSTP topology, SW2’s Gi0/1 port will receive Hellos directly from SW3 (the root). SW2’s Gi0/2 must also receive Hellos identifying SW3 as root, based on the facts stated in the question and the diagram. As a result, SW2’s Gi0/1 port must be an RSTP alternate port.

However, SW1 will not receive Hellos from SW2's G0/2 port, as SW2's G0/2 port is a root port. (Root ports expect to receive Hellos from the neighboring switch, but the switch does not forward Hellos out the root port.)

As for the two answers that mention a backup port, none of the ports can have a backup port role due to the current physical topology. To have a backup port with today's Ethernet devices, one switch must connect more than one port to the same Ethernet segment, typically by connecting two ports to the same LAN hub. The figure shows no LAN hubs, so no ports can become backup ports.

answerChoices.Text: SW2’s port Gi0/1 must be in an alternate port role.
SW1’s port Gi0/1 might be in an alternate port role.
SW2’s port Gi0/1 must be in a backup port role.
SW1’s port Gi0/1 might be in a backup port role.

questionText: Which of the following port states are used by 802.1w RSTP but not by 802.1D STP?
explanation:
RSTP defines one new port state not defined by 802.1D STP: the discarding state. RSTP uses the discarding state instead of the STP blocking and disabled states.

	For the incorrect answers, both STP and RSTP use the learning and forwarding states. Additionally, RSTP does use a unique port role (not port state)—the alternate port role—but there is no STP port state named “alternate.”

questionText: An STP topology with three switches has one link between each pair of switches. Which answer best describes the primary decision point as to which non-root switch has a designated port on the link between switches, and which does not?
explanation:
The device with the lowest root cost becomes the designated port for a segment, and the other switch then moves to blocking state for that link.

	The lowest cost to root is the leading factor in determining who will be designated and who will block. If the costs were equal, the lowest BID between the two nonroot switches would be used to determine who would be designated for that link.

answerChoices.Text: The device with the lowest BID would always become designated, and the other switch would block.
The device with the highest BID would become designated, and the other switch would block.
The switch with the lowest root cost would become designated, and the other switch would block.
The switch with the highest root cost would become designated, and the other switch would block.
The switch with the lowest priority setting would become designated, and the other switch would block.

questionText: What type of port can benefit from using BPDU Guard?
explanation: PortFast and BPDU Guard can be run independently. PortFast-enabled ports bypass the listening and learning states of STP and move into the forwarding state. If another switch is plugged into a PortFast protected port or any other port, BPDUs will be sent over that port. If BPDU Guard is enabled and a BPDU is detected, the port will be put into an err-disabled state. Trunk links are typically between more than one switch and would require the passing of BPDUs between the switches. Layer 3 routed ports do not participate in STP because STP is a Layer 2 construct.

answerChoices.Text: Any port that could have another switch plugged into it by mistake

questionText: What is the purpose of using Root Guard?
explanation: Root Guard is used to prevent unplanned switches from becoming the Root Bridge. Root Guard is configured on a port-by-port basis and listens to the BPDUs and determines whether the port receives a superior BPDU. If a superior BPDU is received, Root Guard prevents the election of a different root switch that is reachable through that port. Root Guard doesn’t forward superior BPDUs to another switch; it instead puts the port into what’s called “root-inconsistent” or “broken” state until no superior BPDUs are being received in the hellos. Then the port automatically recovers back to a functioning state. Inferior BPDUs have no impact on Root Guard or the operational state of the port.

answerChoices.Text: To forward superior BPDUs to the root switch
To forward superior BPDUs to the secondary root switch
To disable the port when it receives an inferior BPDU
To disable the port when it receives a superior BPDU

questionText: The exhibit shows a diagram of a small switched network. All switches use layer 2 switching and no layer 3 switching. The diagram identifies the root switch (switch SW1), and all root ports (RP) and designated ports (DP) for VLAN 10. All switches have the spanning-tree mode rapid-pvst command configured. The answers list ports that are neither root port nor designated port. Choose the answer that lists an RSTP port role that is meaningful for that port in this topology.

answerChoices.Text: SW3’s F0/4 could be an RSTP backup port.
SW4’s F0/2 could be an RSTP backup port.
SW2’s G0/2 could be an RSTP backup port.
SW4’s G0/1 could be an RSTP alternate port.
SW3’s F0/4 could be an RSTP alternate port.

questionText: In a VLAN in which all RSTP priorities tie, the current root switch just failed. The answers list the MAC address used in the Bridge ID of the remaining switches. Which switch will take over as the root?
explanation: The switches will elect a new root switch by choosing the switch with the lowest Bridge ID (BID). The Bridge ID uses the bridge priority as the high-order part of the BID, with the switch MAC Address as the last 48 bits. The question tells us that all switches have the same priority, so the switch with the lowest MAC address will win. The switch with MAC address 0004.3265.0125 will become the root bridge as a result.

questionText: When you are configuring EtherChannel between two switches, what are the two channel-group modes that you can configure if one end is using PAgP?
explanation: When you are using the dynamic EtherChannel protocol PAgP, the two channel-group modes you can use are desirable and auto. When you are using the EtherChannel protocol LACP, the two modes that you can use when one side is active are active and passive.

questionText: Which spanning-tree modes are Cisco proprietary?
explanation: Cisco created its own proprietary spanning-tree features, which are Per VLAN Spanning Tree Plus (PVST+) and Rapid Per VLAN Spanning Tree Plus (RPVST+). The other options are IEEE standards.

questionText: Which of the following are LACP modes that you can use with EtherChannel configuration?
explanation:
Active and passive are the two mode choices for LACP.

	Auto and desirable are two modes for PAgP, and the on option indicates that neither LACP nor PAgP messages will be sent.

questionText: The exhibit lists output from a switch. Which two statements are true?
explanation:
For one correct answer, note that the exhibit lists interfaces at the bottom of the output, both in a "desg" or designated role, and just to the right, lists each in a "FWD" or forwarding state.

For the other correct answer, from memory, you should recall at the default base STP priority is 32,768. The exhibit lists the local switch's priority as "24606 (priority 24576 sysid-ext-30), confirming that the local switch's priority is lower than the default setting.

For the two incorrect answers:


	The output shows a command specific to VLAN 30, so while the output does confirm that the local switch is the root of VLAN 30, the output says nothing about the switch's role in other VLANs, making the answer “The switch is the root bridge for all the VLANS on this switch” incorrect.
	The command does not let us know how many VLANs are on this switch; therefore, “There are 30 VLANs on this switch” is incorrect.

answerChoices.Text: All designated ports are in forwarding states.
The switch is the root bridge for all the VLANS on this switch.
The bridge priority is lower than the default value for spanning-tree.
There are 30 VLANs on this switch.

questionText: Two switches are connected by four Fast Ethernet trunks. Four VLANs exist, with members of each VLAN on each of the two switches. The network engineer would like to have the switches treat all 4 trunks as a single 400 Mbps trunk, with some of the traffic being forwarded over each of the links between the switches. Which of the following statements are true of such a configuration?
explanation: Ethernet Channels, or EtherChannel for short, combine up to eight parallel links into a single entity for STP logic, with load balancing across the links. The show commands list EtherChannels as PortChannel interfaces, abbreviated Po.

answerChoices.Text: The four trunks can be placed into the same EtherChannel to achieve this goal.
STP can be used to cause balancing over three of the four trunks, blocking on one trunk to prevent loops
The show spanning-tree command will list the combined four links with an abbreviation of EC for EtherChannel.
The show spanning-tree command will list the combined four links with an abbreviation of Po for PortChannel.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit; which statements are true about the output displayed?
explanation: The output shown in the exhibit shows that there is an operational Layer 2 port channel using only one of the two displayed links. You can tell it is operational and in which mode by looking at the status codes after the port-channel interface (‘SU’): the ‘S’ indicates a Layer 2 port channel and the ‘U’ indicates that it is currently in use (operational). The Gi0/2 interface has a ‘P’ status, indicating that it is currently bundled in the port channel (working), while the Gi0/1 interface has a ‘w’ status, indicating that it is currently waiting to be bundled (this happens if both sides of an interface are configured with a passive dynamic mode, in this case PAgP auto mode).

answerChoices.Text: The port channel displayed is operational.
The port channel is only operational using all displayed interfaces.
The port channel displayed is non-operational.
This is a Layer 3 port channel.
This is a Layer 2 port channel.
The port channel is only operational using a single interface.

questionText: Which spanning-tree modes are IEEE standards?
explanation: Cisco created its own proprietary spanning-tree features; they are Per VLAN Spanning Tree Plus (PVST+) and Rapid Per-VLAN Spanning Tree Plus (RPVST+). The other options are IEEE standards.

questionText: When configuring interfaces to be part of the same EtherChannel, which of the following should you configure identically?
explanation:
Speed, duplex, allowed VLANS on trunk ports, and the same access VLAN on access ports should all match for interfaces belonging to the EtherChannel bundle.

	The MAC addresses for the ports do not have to match, but all the other listed parameters must match.

answerChoices.Text: Access VLAN on an access port
MAC addresses on a trunk or access port

questionText: Which EtherChannel command uses the Cisco proprietary dynamic protocol?
comments: 11/16 - ok as-is  "Note that the question lists the correct single answer. As noted in the explanation, “on” means that no protocol is used, so it can’t be correct. “active” and “passive” mean the IEEE standard protocol LACP is used, so that’s not Cisco proprietary. That leaves the one command that uses “desirable”, which happens to cause the switch to use Cisco proprietary PAgP, making that one correct."  , 11/16 - query to Au

questionText: Based on the exhibit provided, what two things are true?
explanation: You can see that the priority is 32768 + the VLAN ID of 10 = 32778. You also can see that SW2 is running in RSTP mode based on the message “Spanning tree enabled protocol rstp.” In addition, you can tell that SW2 is the root bridge for VLAN 10 in a couple of ways. First, it specifically says “This bridge is the root.” Second, none of the ports are root ports and they are all designated forwarding ports. Finally, the output lists cost 4 beside each Gigabit interface; cost 4 is the default STP/RSTP cost on ports running at Gigabit speed.

answerChoices.Text: SW2 has a bridge priority of 4096.
SW2 uses default STP costs on the interfaces shown.
SW2 is the root bridge for VLAN 10.

questionText: When you are configuring EtherChannel between two switches, what are the two channel-group modes that you can configure if one end is using PAgP?
explanation: When you are using the dynamic EtherChannel protocol PAgP, the two channel-group modes you can use are desirable and auto. When you are using the EtherChannel protocol LACP, the two modes that you can use when one side is active are active and passive.

questionText: When you are configuring spanning-tree vlan X root primary, the switch will look at the current priority of the root switch and choose either ______ .
explanation: The switch will look at the current priority of the root bridge’s priority and will choose either 24,576 or 4096 less than the current root’s priority. The command spanning-tree vlan X root secondary will use 28,672. The other options are not correct.

answerChoices.Text: 24,576 or 4096 less than the current root’s priority
28,672 or 4096 less than the current root’s priority
32767 or 4096 less than the current root’s priority
65535 or 4096 less than the current root’s priority

questionText: Switch 1 and Switch 2 are connected with four links to form an EtherChannel. What configuration settings on the two switches would cause problems with the Etherchannel?
explanation:
When configuring an EtherChannel between two devices, these settings need to match between the two switches:

	- Speed of all links

	- Duplex of all links

	- Native vlans on trunks

	- Same negotiation protocol either LACP or PaGP

	- Operational mode: access or trunk

	- STP interface settings

	The two correct answers list reasons that would cause problems, namely a native VLAN mismatch and a speed mismatch. The two incorrect answer list settings that would not cause issues. First, the channel-group number is locally significant, that is, switch 1 can use group 1 for all its links, with switch 2 using another number for all its links. For the other incorrect answer, the answer states a working scenario with both switches using LACP.

answerChoices.Text: Switch 1 configured for channel-group 1, while Switch 2 uses channel-group 2
Both switches configured to use LACP
Speed mismatch on SW1 and SW2 interfaces.
Native VLAN mismatch between switch trunk interfaces

questionText: Refer to the exhibit; which statements are true about the input shown?
explanation: The exhibit shows the output of the show etherchannel port-channel command. A lot of useful information can be shown with this command. It shows that there are currently two operational links in the configured port channel: one is configured as active and the other is passive. Since SW2’s Gi0/1 link is operational, the remote interface must be configured as active or the interface wouldn’t be included in the port channel. The output also shows that the protocol being used is LACP (which can also be derived from the modes) and that the port channel is currently operational; if it were not operational, none of the links would be displayed.

answerChoices.Text: The remote interface connected to SW2’s Gi0/1 interface must be configured as passive.
The Dynamic EtherChannel protocol configured is PAgP.
The remote interface connected to SW2’s Gi0/1 interface must be configured as active.
The Dynamic EtherChannel protocol configured is LACP.
The Port Channel (EtherChannel) link is operational.
The Port Channel (EtherChannel) link is non-operational.

questionText: What is the issue with the network in the following figure?
explanation: In the figure, a broadcast storm is occurring due to improper configuration of Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) for loop avoidance. MAC table thrashing could occur due to the loop in the figure; however, the figure does not show evidence to prove MAC table thrashing is occurring. Although STP is not configured, duplication of unicast frames is not evident in the figure. STP is a loop avoidance mechanism; it will not propagate loops.

answerChoices.Text: STP is not configured and a broadcast storm is occurring.
STP is not configured and duplication of unicast frames is occurring.

questionText: Which command will show the number of entries in a MAC address table?
explanation: The command to show the current MAC address entry count in the MAC address table is show mac address-table count. This command will also show the maximum number of entries the table can hold. The command show mac address-table is incorrect, as it will show the contents of the MAC address table in the switch. The commands show mac count and show cam count are incorrect.

questionText: When a switch receives a frame, what does it use to make a forwarding decision?
explanation: Forward filter decisions are made upon the destination MAC address in the frame. The source MAC address is used for MAC address learning to build the forward/filter table. The source and destination IP address in the frame is no concern of the switch. Only a router would decapsulate the frame further to make routing decisions upon the destination IP address.

answerChoices.Text: Destination MAC address in the frame
Source MAC address in the frame
Source IP address in the frame
Destination IP address in the frame

questionText: From the following figure, what can you conclude about the computer with the MAC address of 0002.160a.4c37?
explanation: The computer is on another switch connected via a trunk link since there are multiple VLANs on the interface of Gi0/1. This is also evidence that the computer is not the only device on port Gi0/1. It cannot be concluded that the computer is on a hub connected to port Gi0/1. The computers MAC address has not aged out of the table yet because it can still be seen in the figure.

answerChoices.Text: The computer is the only device on port Gi0/1.
The computer is on a hub connected to port Gi0/1.
The computer is connected to another switch.
The computers MAC address has aged out of the table.

questionText: Which type of switchport strips all VLAN information from the frame before it egresses the interface on the switch?
explanation: Access ports strip all VLAN information before the frame egresses the destination interface. The endpoint on an access switch port will never see any of the VLAN information that was associated with the frame. A trunk port will carry the frame along with the VLAN information until it gets to the other side of the trunk link. Voice ports also carry the frame along with VLAN tagging information. A Dynamic Trunking Protocol (DTP) port will form a trunk port to another switch; therefore, it is a trunking protocol, not a switchport type.

questionText: Which is a correct statement about the following figure?
explanation: The switch has negotiated with the adjacent switch to become a trunk and set its trunking protocol to 802.1Q. The letter n in front of 802.1Q specifies it was negotiated. When a switch is set to auto for the Dynamic Trunking Protocol (DTP), it will respond to trunking requests but will not initiate DTP messages. The adjacent switch must be set to desirable since the desirable mode will send DTP messages. The native VLAN does not show it has been changed, since VLAN 1 is the default native VLAN as it is configured in the figure. The figure does not show evidence that the switch is sending DTP frames. Evidence also does not exist in the figure to support the theory that the adjacent switch is also set for auto DTP.

answerChoices.Text: The default native VLAN has been changed.
The switch is sending DTP frames.
The adjacent switch is also set to auto for DTP.

questionText: You check the status of the EtherChannel configured on the switch with the show etherchannel command. What can be concluded from the output? Refer to the following figure.
explanation: The EtherChannel has been configured with no control protocol, which is a result of configuring each side of the EtherChannel with the command channel-group 1 mode on. The figure shows no evidence that the EtherChannel is configured with either Port Aggregation Protocol (PAgP) or Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP). The figure also shows no evidence that the EtherChannel is configured as an access port.

answerChoices.Text: The EtherChannel is configured with PAgP.
The EtherChannel is configured with LACP.
The EtherChannel is configured with no control protocol.
The EtherChannel is configured as an access port.

questionText: You are configuring an EtherChannel between two switches. You check your configuration on the first switch and are ready to configure the second switch. What mode do you need to configure on the other switch? Refer to the following figure.
explanation: Since the auto mode was used on the first switch (Switch A), desirable should be used on the second switch to assure forming of an EtherChannel by using the command channel-group 1 mode desirable. If both sides are set to auto with the command channel-group 1 mode auto, then the EtherChannel will not be built. The commands channel-group 1 mode active and channel-group 1 mode passive are used for Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP) configuration.

questionText: You are configuring an EtherChannel between two switches for trunking. The EtherChannel will not form. You check your configuration on the first switch. What is the problem on the other switch? Refer to the following figure.
explanation: If the other switch is set to passive mode, an EtherChannel will not form. The recommended mode for the other side is active mode. The figure also shows no evidence that the EtherChannel is configured as an access port. The Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) has no effect on an EtherChannel. The EtherChannel has been configured for Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP), noted by the channel-group 1 mode passive command.

answerChoices.Text: The other switch is configured as an access link.
The other switch has CDP turned off.
The other switch is configured for active mode.
The other switch is configured for passive mode.

questionText: In the following figure, Rapid Spanning Tree Protocol (RSTP) is configured. Which interfaces will become the root ports?
explanation: Switch B has the lowest MAC address of all of the switches. Therefore, Switch B will become the RSTP root bridge. All ports leading back to Switch B will become the root ports. Switch A interface Gi1/8, Switch D interface Fa2/16, and Switch C interface Gi1/3 will become root ports. All of the other options are incorrect.

answerChoices.Text: Switch B interface Fa1/5 and Gi1/12
Switch A interface Gi1/8 and Switch D interface Fa2/16
Switch A interface Gi1/8, Switch D interface Fa2/16, and Switch C interface Gi1/3
Switch A interface Gi1/2 and Switch D interface Gi1/8

questionText: When youre using 802.1w, which switchport state will always forward traffic?
explanation: The 802.1w Rapid Spanning Tree Protocol (RSTP) defines that designated switchports always forward traffic. The designated port is a port that is forwarding traffic and is opposite of the root port or blocking port if it is a redundant link. A disabled switchport does not participate in RSTP or the forwarding of traffic. A backup port is a redundant port on the same switch and segment that is placed in a blocking mode in the event the forwarding port is unable to forward traffic. An alternate port is a redundant port on the same segment, but different switches. The alternate port is placed in a blocking mode, and in the event the forwarding port is unable to forward traffic, the alternate port will forward traffic.

questionText: You want to quickly configure an edge switch so all access ports are in PortFast mode. Which command will achieve this?
explanation: The command spanning-tree portfast default will configure all access ports on the switch as PortFast enabled. The commands switchport spanning-tree portfast, spanning-tree portfast enable, and spanning-tree portfast are incorrect.

questionText: Which AP mode allows for RF analysis of the 802.11ac radio spectrum?
explanation: Monitor mode can be used for analysis of the radio spectrum. Analysis mode is not a real mode; therefore, it is an incorrect option. FlexConnect mode is a switching mode on the wireless access point (WAP) in which traffic is switched directly to the intended destination. Local mode is a switching mode on the wireless access point in which all traffic is directed to the wireless controller before being switched to the intended destination.

questionText: You have a small area in a warehouse in which you need wired connectivity to the network. However, wiring cannot be run easily, but there is a direct line of sight for wireless. Which AP feature can be used to connect the area?
explanation: WorkGroup Bridge mode allows you to connect an AP to another AP via an SSID. The Ethernet connection is then bridged over to allow other wired connections to share the wireless bridge. A wireless mesh is used for wireless coverage where wired APs cannot be installed. LightWeight mode is a wireless AP mode in which the wireless LAN controller controls the AP. Local mode is a switching mode on the wireless access point (WAP) in which all traffic is directed to the wireless controller before being switched to the intended destination.

questionText: You need to configure a link aggregation group for a Cisco wireless controller. What should be configured on the EtherChannel to establish a link?
explanation: When an EtherChannel is configured to an on mode, it means that no negotiation protocol will be used to build the EtherChannel. If the mode of auto or desirable is configured on the EtherChannel interfaces, then the EtherChannel will participate in Port Aggregation Protocol (PAgP). If the mode of passive is configured on the EtherChannel interfaces, then the EtherChannel will participate in Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP).

questionText: You have been given the task of mapping a network. You have several routers and switches that are interconnected. Which Cisco tool will help you map the network?
explanation: The Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) can be used to map out all of the Cisco devices connected to the network. If you issue the command show cdp neighbors detail or show cdp entry *, the output will display all of the Cisco devices connected to the switch or router the command is issue from. The running configuration will not display the current devices connected. The Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) or Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol (EIGRP) protocol will not display the directly connected devices.

questionText: Which command would you use to reset the MAC address table for learned MAC addresses in a switch?
explanation: The command used to reset the MAC address table is clear mac-address-table dynamic. The commands reset mac address-table, clear mac-address-table, and clear mac table are incorrect.

questionText: When a switch receives a frame, what does it use to make a forwarding decision?
explanation: Forward filter decisions are made upon the destination MAC address in the frame. The source MAC address is used for MAC address learning to build the forward/filter table. The source and destination IP address in the frame is no concern of the switch. Only a router would decapsulate the frame further to make routing decisions upon the destination IP address.

answerChoices.Text: Destination MAC address in the frame
Source MAC address in the frame
Source IP address in the frame
Destination IP address in the frame

questionText: From the following figure, what can you conclude about the computer with the MAC address of 0002.160a.4c37?
explanation: The computer is on another switch connected via a trunk link since there are multiple VLANs on the interface of Gi0/1. This is also evidence that the computer is not the only device on port Gi0/1. It cannot be concluded that the computer is on a hub connected to port Gi0/1. The source interface is Fa0/2 with a destination interface of Fa0/1.
The source interface is Fa0/1 with a destination interface of Fa0/2 via VLAN 2.
The source interface is Fa0/1 and VLAN 2 with a destination interface of Fa0/2.

questionText: Which type of switchport strips all VLAN information from the frame before it egresses the interface on the switch?
explanation: Access ports strip all VLAN information before the frame egresses the destination interface. The endpoint on an access switch port will never see any of the VLAN information that was associated with the frame. A trunk port will carry the frame along with the VLAN information until it gets to the other side of the trunk link. Voice ports also carry the frame along with VLAN tagging information. A Dynamic Trunking Protocol (DTP) port will form a trunk port to another switch; therefore, it is a trunking protocol, not a switchport type.

questionText: Which is a correct statement about the following figure?
explanation: The switch has negotiated with the adjacent switch to become a trunk and set its trunking protocol to 802.1Q. The letter n in front of 802.1Q specifies it was negotiated. When a switch is set to auto for the Dynamic Trunking Protocol (DTP), it will respond to trunking requests but will not initiate DTP messages. The adjacent switch must be set to desirable since the desirable mode will send DTP messages. The native VLAN does not show it has been changed, since VLAN 1 is the default native VLAN as it is configured in the figure. The figure does not show evidence that the switch is sending DTP frames. Evidence also does not exist in the figure to support the theory that the adjacent switch is also set for auto DTP.

questionText: You check the status of the EtherChannel configured on the switch with the show etherchannel command. What can be concluded from the output? Refer to the following figure.
explanation: The EtherChannel has been configured with no control protocol, which is a result of configuring each side of the EtherChannel with the command channel-group 1 mode on. The figure shows no evidence that the EtherChannel is configured with either Port Aggregation Protocol (PAgP) or Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP). The figure also shows no evidence that the EtherChannel is configured as an access port.

answerChoices.Text: One of the switches is configured with on mode and the other with desirable mode.
One of the switches is configured with auto mode and the other with desirable mode.
